title: AAQ: Why Does Krishna Let Us Suffer? | His Grace Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa
speaker: HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa

segments.key_quote: So, if God is all merciful, why doesn't he protect his devotees all the time?
segments.summary: The lecture begins by posing the question of why Krishna allows suffering, especially among devotees, despite being merciful.
segments.transcript: This question is, why does Krishna allow us to suffer if he is always merciful? Good question. If God is all merciful, if he is all kind, why does he allow living entities to suffer in the material world? Why do we see suffering in the material world? Like we also hear, there was a pilgrimage. Some people were going in a bus to Kedarnath. Suddenly the bus fell down, had an accident and all the people died. Or there was some flood and the people who were on pilgrimage, they got killed. Or somebody was going for Navaratri and they were going on a pilgrimage somewhere and they met with an accident and they died. So, why do the devotees of God, they are religious people, they are pious people, why is God not protecting them? Such people, the religious people also suffer. They also have to undergo disease. They also have to undergo so many other distresses. They have to become old. They also have to die. So, if God is all merciful, why doesn't he protect his devotees all the time? So, the point is, Krishna tells in the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says, my devotee will never be vanquished. So, if you see in the battlefield of Kurukshetra, so many big, big generals were there. Personalities like Bhishma, Karna, Dronacharya, Kripacharya, all big, big generals, Duryodhana himself, they were all powerful fighters, warriors. Arjuna was no match for all of them. But still, at the end of the day, he was a great warrior. At the end of the battle of Kurukshetra, who survived? Pandavas survived. Entire Kaurava army was wiped out. Why? Because Krishna was protecting Arjuna. So, Krishna protects Arjuna. Why not all of us? Right? Then why do people who are going on a pilgrimage, they are going to Kedarnath, Badrinath, why are they getting killed? Why are they suffering? If you see, all the people who are going on pilgrimages, they will all have some prayer. Some problem is there. Some financial problem. Health problem is there. Health problem is there. Relational problem is there. They are going, they undertake these severe austerities. Why? Because they want their problem to be solved. And these people, they are going to God, praying to him for solving their problem. And instead, what happens? They get killed. What is this? God is not merciful.

segments.key_quote: To the extent we surrender unto Krishna, to that extent, Krishna will protect us.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Krishna's protection is proportional to one's surrender and faith, using Arjuna's unwavering conviction as an example.
segments.transcript: So, the point we have to understand is, when Krishna says, Krishna says, My devotee will never be vanquished. There are two aspects to this statement from Krishna. There is another statement of Krishna also in the Bhagavad Gita, where Krishna says, To the extent we surrender unto Krishna, to that extent, Krishna will protect us. So, if we are partially surrendered to Krishna, something I am keeping for myself and something for Krishna also, then Krishna's protection also will be to that extent. If my faith in Krishna is not protected, then Krishna's protection also will be to that extent. If my faith in Krishna is not protected, then Krishna's protection also will be to that extent. Krishna will protect me. How much do we have faith in that understanding, in that conviction? Arjuna was fully convinced, Krishna is my sole protector. How do we know Arjuna was fully convinced of this? When Duryodhana and Arjuna went to Krishna seeking help for the battle of Kurukshetra, Krishna, what did Krishna tell Arjuna? Krishna told Arjuna and Duryodhana, Krishna told Arjuna and Duryodhana, I will divide myself: one side my entire yadava army with all their modern weaponry, all their general soldiers, chariots, elephants, all of that, all the action; on the other hand, myself. I will not lift any weapon. I, all alone, unarmed, will be there on the other side. You choose which one you want. Without batting an eyelid, Arjuna said, I want you. Arjuna said, I want you. So Duryodhana was very happy. He said, ah, Arjuna is such a fool. He is taking Krishna. Okay, if Krishna and said I will fight for you, then okay, you can think because Krishna is powerful warrior. But Krishna said I will not lift any weapon, so what is the use of taking him? So I got all the army, he said, and he walked out. So when Duryodhana walked out, Krishna asked Arjuna, Arjuna, what with what intelligence, what happened to your intelligence? Why did you choose me? I said I will not fight, I will not lift a weapon, then why did you choose me? So Arjuna said, my dear Krishna, you are all alone, no need of any army soldier. One thing is required, you alone are capable of leading this battle. I know if you stand on one side, no army in the world can defeat you. Although you may be unarmed, but still at the same time, by your grace and your devotee, you will ensure that I will also be victorious. I also know that. But at the same time, I want that the credit for the victory in this battle should go to you. People should say because Krishna was there on the side of the Pandavas, the Pandavas won. So therefore I chose you. See Arjuna's conviction, even before the battle began, he knew that he was going to win because Krishna is there on his side.

segments.key_quote: To the extent we are surrendered to Krishna, to that extent Krishna will protect.
segments.summary: The speaker recounts Prahlad Maharaj drinking poison unharmed due to his complete surrender and devotion, emphasizing that Krishna responds to devotion and surrender, like a father favoring an obedient child.
segments.transcript: And if Krishna protects, then no material, uh, challenge or material problem can affect you. Prahlad Maharaj was fully convinced of this. So therefore, when his father, He told Prahlad Maharaj's mother that I've tried killing Prahlad in many ways. I tried putting him into a poison, into a pit full of poisonous snakes. I tried dipping him into a pot of boiling oil. I tried throwing him from the top of a cliff. I tried getting elephants to trample him to death. Nothing is working. So I've decided we have to give him poison. And he took a glass of poison and gave it to his wife and told, feed this to your son. So the mother started crying, how will I feed poison to my son? And Prahlad Maharaj saw his mother crying and he said, why are you crying? He said, what to do my son, your father has said, I have to feed you poison. And then Prahlad Maharaj said, okay, no problem, mother, you give me the poison. Because if you don't give me that poison, my father is such a cruel and evil man. He will make you drink that poison. So give it to me. No problem. I'll drink it. So Prahlad Maharaj confidently took that poison and he said, if Krishna wants, he will protect me. And if Krishna doesn't want, I will die. So therefore the poison, the elephants, the venomous snakes, nothing could kill him. Nothing could hurt him. So this is not unnatural because we have to understand that if there is a person in this material world and he has a son or a daughter who is very obedient and devoted to the father, and there is another child who is rebellious, always not listening to the father and always working contradictorily to the father's instructions, now if there is a situation where the father has to save one of the child, one of the children, whom will he choose? Naturally first he will try to save the child who is obedient, no? Natural. Similarly Krishna also. He will first protect. He will first protect. He will give his full protection to one who is fully surrendered to him.

segments.key_quote: Ultimately Krishna's protection is for the soul, not for the body.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that while devotees still face physical challenges, Krishna's ultimate protection is the liberation of the soul from repeated birth and death, offering a return to Godhead.
segments.transcript: This is one thing. Another thing we have to understand is no matter even if we become a pure devotee, fully surrendered to Krishna, still one day or the other we have to die. Still old age will come, still disease will come because this is the material body. Material body will become diseased, it will become old, it will become destroyed at one point of time. But we, spirit soul, are eternal. We are eternal. We are not going to get destroyed. Body may get destroyed, but we will not get destroyed. Avinashituti tadviddhi, yena sarvam etan tatam. This body is pervaded by the soul. It's pervaded by our consciousness. So even though the body may get destroyed, we will not get destroyed. So ultimately Krishna's protection is for the soul, not for the body. For the body also, Krishna will give protection if it is essential. Like Krishna protected Arjuna and Prahlad Mahabharata. Like Krishna protected Arjuna and Prahlad Mahabharata. But then Over and above that is Krishna's protection from repeated birth and death within the material world. segments.key_quote: The moment we fully surrender to Krishna, no matter how much sinful activities we have accumulated in our past lives, Krishna says, all of that finished.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating that suffering arises from the law of karma for those not fully surrendered, but complete surrender to Krishna nullifies past sins and guarantees protection and liberation, emphasizing Krishna's mercy and impartiality.
segments.transcript: So Krishna has said, either you don't surrender to me, then you are governed by the law of karma. So therefore there is suffering in the material world. Somebody may have partially surrendered to Krishna. He may be a devotee of Krishna, but still he has done some sinful activity.
